(Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/jwk-utils/src/lib.rs] [Function: fetch_jwks_uri_from_openid_config()] [Protocol Downgrade] Is the config_url required to use HTTPS, or can an attacker provide an HTTP URL that allows network attackers to inject a malicious jwks_uri through response manipulation? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/jwk-utils/src/lib.rs] [Function: fetch_jwks_from_jwks_uri()] [URL Parsing] Can an attacker craft URLs with encoded characters, Unicode homoglyphs, or URL fragments that bypass validation but resolve to malicious endpoints (e.g., 'https://trusted.com@evil.com/')? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/jwk-utils/src/lib.rs] [Function: fetch_jwks_from_jwks_uri()] [HTTP Redirect] Can an attacker control the OpenID provider to issue HTTP redirects that change HTTPS to HTTP or redirect to malicious domains, bypassing security checks through redirect chains? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/jwk-utils/src/lib.rs] [Function: fetch_jwks_uri_from_openid_config()] [Request Timeout] Can an attacker make the OpenID configuration endpoint hang indefinitely without timeout, preventing validators from obtaining JWKs and halting keyless account authentication? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/jwk-utils/src/lib.rs] [Function: fetch_jwks_from_jwks_uri()] [Response Size Limit] Is there a maximum response size limit, or can a malicious provider return gigabytes of data in the JWKs response causing memory exhaustion and validator crashes? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/jwk-utils/src/lib.rs] [Function: fetch_jwks_uri_from_openid_config()] [Response Size] Can an attacker provide an OpenID configuration response with extremely large JSON payloads that exhaust validator memory during deserialization? (High)
